column4: I was just listening to something a little while ago, I installed updates that I didn't really look at.  Now I have no sound
after rebooting
and rebooting again
I am running an older kernel b/c the ACPI wasn't working out in the newer ones (I think I am running edgy)
my laptop loved ubuntu for a bout a year until a couple of minutes ago
You can remove the volume control from the panel by right-clicking the speaker icon on the panel and selecting "Remove From Panel" from the menu.
is there anyway I can see what I just installed?
that's funny, never seen that
cat: write error: No space left on device
Pogonip, sudo -i
or your /dev/dsp has the wrong device type
sudo aptitude show linux-restricted-modules-`uname -r` | grep State
State: installed
this is an old P4 Toshiba Satellite
what does (ls -l /dev/dsp) say?
that first dash on the line should be a "c"
, Pogonip_ : it should be something like crw-rw---- 1 root audio 14, 3 2007-11-07 20:53 /dev/dsp
maybe it will be okay in a while with a few reboots, this laptop is pretty solid, but known for anomalies
how can I change it?
so how does one change one's /dev/dsp back to a character device when it's become a file???
I give up, how?
I am not sure, I think you have to run mknod but hold on
